questions.prompt: Which muscle type is voluntary and most often addressed in massage sessions?
questions.why: Skeletal muscle is under voluntary control and is the main tissue targeted by manual therapy.
questions.trap: Smooth muscle is involuntary and lines organs.

questions.prompt: A muscle tissue ability to respond to a nerve signal is called:
questions.why: Excitability is the ability to receive and react to stimulation.

questions.prompt: The ability of muscle to shorten and produce force is:
questions.why: Contractility is the force-producing shortening property.
questions.trap: Extensibility is about lengthening, not forceful shortening.

questions.prompt: The ability of muscle to lengthen without damage is:
questions.why: Extensibility is controlled stretch capacity.
questions.trap: Elasticity is return to original length.

questions.prompt: The ability of stretched muscle to return toward resting length is:
questions.why: Elasticity is recoil after stretch.
questions.trap: Threshold is stimulus level, not recoil behavior.

questions.prompt: Indirect attachment from muscle to bone is most commonly via:
questions.why: Tendon is dense connective tissue linking muscle to bone.
questions.hook: Tendon transmits muscle force to bone.

questions.prompt: Which connective tissue wraps the entire muscle?
questions.why: Epimysium surrounds the whole muscle.

questions.prompt: Which connective tissue surrounds a fascicle?
questions.why: Perimysium wraps each fascicle bundle.

questions.prompt: Which connective tissue wraps an individual muscle fiber?
questions.why: Endomysium surrounds one muscle fiber.
questions.trap: Epimysium is the outermost whole muscle layer.

questions.prompt: A fascicle is best defined as:
questions.why: Fascicles are bundles of many fibers.

questions.prompt: A myofibril is:

choices.B: A contractile rod inside a muscle fiber

questions.answer: A contractile rod inside a muscle fiber.
questions.why: Myofibrils are rod-like contractile structures inside fibers.
questions.trap: Fascicles are bundles of fibers, not internal rods.

questions.prompt: The smallest repeating functional contractile unit is the:
questions.why: Sarcomere is the basic repeating contractile unit.
questions.trap: Motor unit is neuron plus fibers.

questions.prompt: In the sliding filament model, thin filaments are primarily:
questions.why: Actin forms the thin filaments.

questions.prompt: In the sliding filament model, thick filaments are primarily:
questions.why: Myosin forms the thick filament with heads that pull.

questions.prompt: During contraction, actin and myosin:
questions.why: Filaments slide, shortening the sarcomere overall.
questions.trap: Individual filaments do not shorten significantly.

questions.prompt: The sarcoplasmic reticulum primarily stores and releases:
questions.why: SR calcium release enables cross-bridge cycling.
questions.trap: Acetylcholine is from motor neurons, not SR.

questions.prompt: Calcium binds to which protein to allow cross-bridge access?
questions.why: Calcium binds troponin, shifting tropomyosin.
questions.trap: Myoglobin stores oxygen, not regulatory gating.

questions.prompt: ATP is directly required in contraction because it:
questions.why: ATP powers cross-bridge detachment and re-priming.
questions.trap: Without ATP, heads stay bound more rigidly.

questions.prompt: If ATP is unavailable, muscle is most likely to become:
questions.why: Low ATP limits myosin detachment, increasing rigidity.
questions.trap: Nerve signaling and ATP chemistry are separate steps.

questions.prompt: A motor unit consists of:

choices.B: One motor neuron and the fibers it innervates
choices.D: One nerve root and one ligament

questions.answer: One motor neuron and the fibers it innervates.
questions.why: Motor unit is neuron plus all fibers it controls.
questions.trap: Fascicle is structural, not neural control.
questions.hook: One nerve controls its fiber team.

questions.prompt: Recruiting additional motor units generally:
questions.why: More recruited units produce greater total force.
questions.trap: Recruitment does not eliminate fatigue entirely.

questions.prompt: For precise, small movement control, muscles usually use:
questions.why: Small motor units allow finer gradation of force.
questions.trap: Large units are better for gross force tasks.

questions.prompt: Threshold in muscle physiology is the:
questions.why: Threshold is the least stimulus that triggers a contraction response.

questions.prompt: A twitch is best described as:
questions.why: A twitch is a single brief response to one stimulus.

questions.prompt: Treppe refers to:

choices.B: Progressive increase in twitch force with repeated stimuli and rest

questions.answer: Progressive increase in twitch force with repeated stimuli and rest.
questions.why: Treppe is staircase-like rise in contraction force.
questions.trap: No relaxation pattern is tetanus, not treppe.

questions.prompt: Incomplete tetanus means:
questions.why: Contractions are close enough to summate but still partially relax.
questions.trap: No relaxation at all defines complete tetanus.

questions.prompt: Complete tetanus means:
questions.why: Stimulus frequency is high enough for fused contraction.

questions.prompt: Increasing stimulation frequency usually raises force due to:
questions.why: Successive twitches can add together as wave summation.
questions.trap: Ligament recoil is not the main force mechanism.

questions.prompt: Isometric contraction is when muscle:

choices.C: Generates tension with little length change

questions.answer: Generates tension with little length change.
questions.why: Isometric work creates force without visible length change.

questions.prompt: Concentric contraction is when muscle:
questions.why: Concentric action shortens muscle to move load.

questions.prompt: Eccentric contraction is when muscle:
questions.why: Eccentric work is controlled lengthening with tension.

questions.prompt: In movement analysis, the agonist is the muscle that:
questions.why: Agonist is the prime mover for the action.

questions.prompt: The antagonist in a movement primarily:

choices.B: Opposes or controls the agonist action

questions.answer: Opposes or controls the agonist action.
questions.why: Antagonists oppose or brake the prime mover.

questions.prompt: A synergist is a muscle that:
questions.why: Synergists support the agonist and refine movement.

questions.prompt: A fixator primarily:

choices.B: Stabilizes a segment so movers can act

questions.answer: Stabilizes a segment so movers can act.
questions.why: Fixators stabilize origin or nearby joints.
questions.trap: Prime movers produce most visible action.

questions.prompt: Flexion generally means:
questions.why: Flexion usually decreases the joint angle.

questions.prompt: Extension generally means:
questions.why: Extension commonly increases the angle at a joint.

questions.prompt: Abduction is movement:
questions.why: Abduction moves a segment away from midline.

questions.prompt: Adduction is movement:
questions.why: Adduction brings a segment toward midline.

questions.prompt: Internal rotation at a limb generally turns the anterior surface:
questions.why: Internal rotation turns the front surface inward.

questions.prompt: External rotation at a limb generally turns the anterior surface:
questions.why: External rotation turns the front surface outward.

questions.prompt: The immediate usable energy currency for muscle contraction is:
questions.why: ATP directly powers cross-bridge cycling.
questions.trap: Glycogen is stored fuel, not immediate currency.

questions.prompt: For very brief high-intensity effort, ATP is rapidly regenerated mainly by:
questions.why: Creatine phosphate quickly donates phosphate to regenerate ATP.
questions.trap: Protein oxidation is not the immediate burst pathway.

questions.prompt: Anaerobic glycolysis is most associated with:
questions.why: Anaerobic glycolysis supports short intense effort when demand rises.
questions.trap: Aerobic metabolism dominates long lower-intensity output.

questions.prompt: Aerobic metabolism is most useful for:
questions.why: Aerobic pathways support longer-duration work efficiently.
questions.trap: Burst power relies more on ATP-PC and anaerobic pathways.

questions.prompt: In session planning, local muscular fatigue is best described as:
questions.why: Fatigue is a temporary decline in performance capacity.
questions.trap: It does not automatically mean tissue injury.

questions.prompt: A practical recovery support choice after heavy training is:

choices.D: Only static stretching for all clients

questions.why: Hydration and sleep are foundational recovery supports.
questions.trap: Overly aggressive pressure can reduce tolerance in tired tissue.

questions.prompt: After a hard eccentric workout, safest initial massage pressure is often:
questions.why: Progressive pressure respects sensitivity after heavy loading.
questions.trap: Immediate aggressive work may increase guarding.

questions.prompt: If a client reports cramping and obvious fatigue, a good immediate adjustment is:
questions.why: Lowering intensity and reassessing improves safety and tolerance.
questions.trap: Pushing through fatigue can worsen guarding.
questions.hook: Adjust down when tissue is overloaded.

questions.prompt: Sustained strong isometric effort can temporarily:

choices.B: Reduce local perfusion during the hold

questions.answer: Reduce local perfusion during the hold.
questions.why: High sustained tension can compress local vessels temporarily.
questions.trap: Perfusion usually improves once contraction eases.
questions.hook: Hard holds can briefly limit flow.

questions.prompt: A simple strategy to reduce protective muscle guarding during treatment is:

choices.A: Cue slow breathing and gradual pressure

questions.answer: Cue slow breathing and gradual pressure.
questions.why: Breathing and graded pressure support downregulation of guarding.
questions.trap: Abrupt force often increases protective tension.

questions.prompt: A realistic goal after a recovery-focused session is usually:
questions.why: Massage can support readiness and perceived recovery.
questions.trap: It does not replace conditioning progression.

questions.prompt: During resisted elbow flexion, biceps brachii is commonly the:
questions.why: Biceps commonly acts as prime mover in elbow flexion tasks.
questions.trap: Triceps is the typical antagonist for that motion.

questions.prompt: During controlled lowering from elbow flexion, biceps action is often:
questions.why: Biceps can eccentrically control extension while lengthening.
questions.trap: Concentric would shorten during lifting phase.

questions.prompt: When assessing movement quality, a weak stabilizer often leads to:
questions.why: Poor stabilization can cause compensations and altered mechanics.
questions.trap: Compensation is common when base control is limited.

questions.prompt: In session planning for a fatigued client, pacing with more breaks usually:
questions.why: More breaks can improve comfort and quality of work.
questions.trap: Ignoring pacing can overwhelm tired tissue.

questions.prompt: For the first few seconds of a maximal effort, the main ATP backup source is:
questions.why: Creatine phosphate rapidly regenerates ATP in early maximal work.
questions.trap: Fat oxidation is slower and supports longer efforts.

questions.prompt: During longer low-intensity activity, muscles rely more on:
questions.why: Aerobic pathways dominate sustained lower-intensity output.
questions.trap: ATP-PC is mainly brief high-power support.

questions.prompt: If guarding rises during treatment, a safer next step is to:
questions.why: Backing off and reassessing improves tolerance and safety.
questions.trap: Escalating force can increase protective tone.

questions.prompt: In shoulder abduction, middle deltoid often functions as the:
questions.why: Middle deltoid commonly acts as a prime mover for abduction.

questions.prompt: The property meaning ability to respond to a stimulus is:
questions.why: Excitability is response capacity to stimulation.

questions.prompt: The property meaning ability to shorten and generate force is:
questions.why: Contractility describes active forceful shortening.

questions.prompt: The property meaning ability to lengthen without injury is:
questions.why: Extensibility is controlled stretch capacity.

questions.prompt: The property meaning return toward original length after stretch is:
questions.why: Elasticity is recoil behavior.

questions.prompt: A bundle of muscle fibers is called a:
questions.why: Fascicles group many fibers.

questions.prompt: The smallest repeating contractile unit is the:
questions.why: Sarcomere is the core repeating force unit.

questions.prompt: The thin filament in skeletal muscle is mainly:
questions.why: Actin forms the thin filament.

questions.prompt: The thick filament in skeletal muscle is mainly:
questions.why: Myosin heads drive cross-bridge pulling.

questions.prompt: The organelle that stores calcium for contraction is the:
questions.why: SR regulates calcium availability for contraction.
questions.trap: ACh is released by neurons, not SR.

questions.prompt: One motor neuron and all fibers it controls is a:
questions.why: Motor unit links neural drive to fibers.

questions.prompt: Minimum stimulation needed to trigger a response is called:
questions.why: Threshold is the trigger minimum.
questions.hook: Threshold is the floor to fire.

questions.prompt: A single brief contraction-relaxation response is a:
questions.why: A twitch is one short contraction cycle.

questions.prompt: The staircase rise in force with repeated stimuli is called:
questions.why: Treppe describes stepwise force increase.

questions.prompt: Sustained contraction with partial relaxation between stimuli is:
questions.why: Incomplete tetanus keeps some relaxation intervals.

questions.prompt: Sustained contraction with no relaxation between stimuli is:
questions.why: Very high frequency can create fused contraction.

questions.prompt: Tension with little visible change in muscle length is:
questions.why: Isometric means force without obvious length change.

questions.prompt: Muscle shortening while producing force is:
questions.why: Concentric action shortens under load.

questions.prompt: Muscle lengthening while producing force is:
questions.why: Eccentric controls movement while lengthening.

questions.prompt: The primary mover for a given action is called the:
questions.why: Agonist is the prime mover role.

questions.prompt: A muscle that opposes the prime mover is the:
questions.why: Antagonist counters the agonist action.

questions.prompt: A helper muscle assisting the prime mover is the:
questions.why: Synergists assist and refine movement.

questions.prompt: A muscle that stabilizes a segment so motion can occur is a:
questions.why: Fixators provide stability for efficient movement.

questions.prompt: Movement away from the body midline is:
questions.why: Abduction carries a segment away from center.

questions.prompt: Movement toward the body midline is:
questions.why: Adduction brings the limb back toward center.

questions.prompt: The rapid ATP backup system for short intense effort is:
questions.why: CP quickly regenerates ATP in early high demand.
questions.trap: Aerobic pathways dominate longer duration effort.

questions.prompt: Muscle ability to respond to a nerve signal is called ________.
questions.why: Excitability is response to stimulation.

questions.prompt: Muscle ability to shorten and create force is ________.
questions.why: Contractility is active force generation.

questions.prompt: Muscle ability to lengthen safely is ________.
questions.why: Extensibility is stretch tolerance.

questions.prompt: Return toward resting length after stretch is ________.
questions.why: Elasticity is spring-back behavior.

questions.prompt: A bundle of muscle fibers is called a ________.
questions.why: Fascicles group many fibers together.

questions.prompt: The smallest repeating contractile unit is the ________.
questions.why: Sarcomeres are the basic force units.
questions.trap: Motor unit is neural plus fibers.

questions.prompt: The sarcoplasmic reticulum releases ________ to help contraction begin.
questions.why: Calcium exposure enables actin-myosin interaction.

questions.prompt: One motor neuron and all fibers it controls is a motor ________.
questions.why: Motor unit links one neuron with its fibers.

questions.prompt: Minimum stimulation needed to trigger contraction is ________.
questions.why: Threshold is the minimal trigger level.
questions.trap: Twitch is the brief contraction event.

questions.prompt: A fused sustained contraction with no relaxation is complete ________.
questions.why: Very high frequency can fuse contractions.

questions.prompt: Contraction with force but little muscle length change is ________.
questions.why: Isometric creates tension without obvious length shift.

questions.prompt: When muscle shortens under load, the action is ________.
questions.why: Concentric action shortens the muscle.

questions.prompt: When muscle lengthens under load, the action is ________.
questions.why: Eccentric action lengthens while resisting.

questions.prompt: In a movement, the prime mover is the ________.
questions.why: Agonist is the main action driver.

questions.prompt: Movement away from the body midline is called ________.
questions.why: Abduction moves away from center line.
